title: The Mirror of the Mind of Samantabhadra
text:
The Mirror of the Mind of Samantabhadra () is one of the <a href="Seventeen%20tantras">Seventeen tantras</a> of <a href="Dzogchen">Dzogchen</a> <a href="Upadesha">Upadesha</a>.
English discourse.
In the <a href="Lungi%20Terdz%C3%B6">Lungi Terdzö</a> (Wylie: lung gi gter mdzod) the prose autocommentary by <a href="Longchenpa">Longchenpa</a> (1308 – 1364 or possibly 1369) to his <a href="Ch%C3%B6ying%20Dz%C3%B6">Chöying Dzö</a> (Wylie: chos dbyings mdzod) -- which are numbered amongst the <a href="Seven%20Treasuries">Seven Treasuries</a> (Wylie: mdzod chen bdun) -- the following embedded quotation from this Tantra has been rendered into English by <a href="Richard%20Barron">Barron</a>, "et al." (2001: p. 8) and the Wylie has been secured from Wikisource and interspersed and embedded in the English gloss for <a href="%3Awikt%3Aprobity">probity</a>:
"You should understand that the nature of all phenomena is that of the five aspects of Samantabhadra [chos thams cad kun tu bzang po lnga'i rang bzhin du shes par bya'o]. What are these? you ask [de yang gang zhe na 'di lta ste]. They are Samantabhadra as nature [rang bzhin kun tu bzang po dang], Samantabhadra as adornment [rgyan kun tu bzang po dang], Samantabhadra as teacher [ston pa kun tu bzang po dang], Samantabhadra as awareness [rig pa kun tu bzang po dang], and Samantabhadra as realization [rtogs pa kun tu bzang po'o]."
"Phenomena" in the abovementioned quotation should be understood as a rendering of <a href="Dharma%20%28Buddhism%29">dharmas</a> (Sanskrit) which may also be glossed "constituent factors". "Nature" ("rang bzhin") is an analogue of "<a href="svabhava">svabhava</a>" (Sanskrit). "Awareness" is a gloss of "<a href="rigpa">rigpa</a>" (Tibetan). Though Buddhism is for the most part non-theistic, Dzogchen and other Buddhadharma traditions often personify attributes or qualities with a deity in textual discourse as <a href="Samantabhadra%20%28Bodhisattva%29">Samantabhadra</a> herein is the <a href="Adi-Buddha">Adi-Buddha</a> (to be clearly discerned from the namesake <a href="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a>) and is iconographically "attributeless" and "unadorned", the "primordial Buddha", and Samantabhadra is often so for many textual traditions of Dzogchen in both lineagues of <a href="Bonpo">Bonpo</a> and <a href="Nyingmapa">Nyingmapa</a>. Following Longchenpa, wherever Samantabhadra is <a href="Samantabhadri">Samantabhadri</a> is evident indivisibly in <a href="Yab-yum">Yab-yum</a> (Tibetan).
